}} The 'pronghorn' (Antilocapra americana) is a species of artiodactyl mammal
endemic to interior western and central North America. Though not an antelope,
it is often known colloquially in North America as the 'prong buck', 'pronghorn
antelope', or simply antelope, as it closely resembles the true
antelopes of the Old World and fills a similar ecological niche due to
convergent evolution. Farb, Peter (1970). Ecology. Time Life Books. pp. 126,
136 It is the only surviving member of the family Antilocapridae. Smithsonian Institution. North American Mammals:
[http://www.mnh.si.edu/mna/image_info.cfm?species_id=7 Pronghorn Antilocapra
americana] During the Pleistocene period, 12 antilocaprid species existed
in North America. Hawes, Alex.
[http://nationalzoo.si.edu/publications/zoogoer/2001/6/pronghornssavanna.cfm
Pronghorns - Survivors of the American Savanna], Zoogoer, Nov/Dec 2001
About five existed when humans entered North America and all but A. americana
are now extinct.
